There isn't a rule when it comes to tipping in Australia. Traditionally, tourism industry employees get paid enough that they don't need a tip. 

Locals will tell you not to tip, but it has become more common as a result of Americans traveling to the country.

If you are in a really nice restaurant or bar or any tourist spot, you can tip 10\%%-15\%%.

Tipping is expected in these islands, and you should tip according to the quality of service.\n\nBellboys and porters usually receive $1-$2 per bag, while most other servers, e.g. waiters, taxis, ect receive 15\%%.

Gratuities are seldom included in Canadian restaurants, so it is up to you to provide the tip.

It's customary to tip approximately 15-20\%% on the total bill before tax, less for poor service, more for truly exceptional service.

Many restaurants, may charge an automatic 15\%%-18\%% gratuity for larger groups.

If you are dining or drinking somewhere local, there is no need to tip.

 If you are at a nicer establishment, you might notice a 10\%%-15\%% service charge added to your bill. There is no need to tip anything in addition to that.

Be careful how you use your chopsticks. For example, it is rude to stand them upright in your rice bowl or point them at someone else.

It\'s a good idea to have a few 1 CUC notes on hand when staying in a hotel. When your bags are carried to your room, a 1 CUC tip is acceptable. You might be in the habit of leaving a tip for your maid on the day you check out, but when tipping in Cuba, it\'s more appropriate to level 1 CUC for the maid each day.

Tipping is very appreciated in the DR (Dominican Republic), as wages are extremely low. A dollar to them goes a long way. Guests can leave small items and usually $1 to $2 each morning on the pillows for the maids and just add a little note to let them know that it is for them.

Your bill will include a 15\%% service charge, but locals usually tip 10\%% on top of that.

Looking to save some coin? Just remember there is no need to tip at bars! 

Splitting the bill is considered unsophisticated in France, so always offer to pay the whole bill.

Round up to the nearest euro and consider this their tip, especially when ordering only one item, like a drink.

If you want to leave a more substantial tip (for a larger meal), leave 10\%%-15\%%, and let your service know what you are tipping before you pay.

Water or bread served at restaurants is not free. Asking for tap water is uncommon and frowned upon; the service will often turn down your request.

The way money is used and talked about in Ghana may be very different from what you are used to. Be prepared for people asking you for money, bargaining in shops and make sure you leave a tip for good service!

Although it is not protocol to tip, generally a tip is expected and always appreciated. It is customary to leave a tip for the maid so that he or she cleans your hotel room properly, and when someone goes out of their way to help you, for example, giving you directions.

As words of caution, do not be overly generous, as this may appear that you are flaunting money.

Employees at no tipping resorts can lose their job for accepting gifts or tips. Taxis in Jamaica are mainly non-metered, which means you set the price with the driver before boarding the taxi. It\'s OK to leave a tip during this time.

Tipping is not mandatory or expected.

Offering a cash tip to a waiter is rude and doing so may cause confusion. If you feel the need to tip, put the yen in a small envelope and give it directly to your server.

Do not be afraid to audibly slurp noodles here; it's though to help the eater enjoy the dish more and improve the flavor.

For more structured services, a 100 shilling (roughly $1) tip would be fair enough. At hotels, porters can be tipped anything from 50 shillings to 100 shillings. \n\nYou may give your housekeeper anything from 200 shillings to 500 shillings per week to ensure motivation and good service by her.

At restaurants, it is customary to leave a 10\%%-15\%% tip.

If there is an amount listed as "IVA" on your bill, that's 16\%% of your bill, so you can also tip that instead.

Sometimes the tip will be included in your restaurant bill, so there will be no need to leave any additional tip.

It's completely acceptable to eat with your hands here.

Tipping is appreciated in Niger and, while a service charge is generally added to restaurant bills, extra tips are still appreciated. Taxi drivers, tour guides, barmen and porters all take tips.\n\n10\%% tip is customary. Be careful with over tipping as you may draw unwanted, and even dangerous, attention to yourself.
Locals tip very modestly, leaving behind small change or rounding up to the nearest Euro is common. However, if you are happy with your service, you should tip between 7\%%-15\%% in cash.

Tipping is not expected in the UK in the way it is in other countries. However, a small tip is still considered a nice gesture. If you tip between 10\%% and 12\%% you are too kind. This is enough to display your generosity and satisfaction with the service.

For waiters at sit-down restaurants, bartenders, barbers, hair-dressers, taxi drivers, tour guides, and food delivery, the tip should be calculated as a percentage of your total bill. Tip 10\%% if you are not completely happy. 15\%% indicates that the service was acceptable. And 20\%% means the service was really good.

Q1: Where don’t you tip? 

A1: In Japan, this offering is considered offensive! Because of a tip’s nature as a gift or a favor, it can be perceived as an implication of servility. 

Q2: Where do you tip? 

A2: Pretty much everywhere else! It is never embarrassing to leave a tip on the table. In fact, in countries where it isn’t required it is all the more appreciated. But in the US, tipping is almost a mandatory requirement. This is why it is important to know the rules for tipping. How much do you tip? And what are reasonable tip amounts? 

Q3: How to determine the tippable total? 

A3: Using applications like a Tip Calculator is a wonderful first step to ensuring that you are issuing good tips! But here are a couple unspoken rules. First, if you used any coupons or discounts, calculate the tip based on how much you would have paid without it. Otherwise you are punishing the server for the restaurant management’s efforts to entice you through the front door. For example, if you have a 2-for-1 coupon (two-fer!), you may only have had to pay for half of your meal, but the waiter still did the full amount of work. 

Also, if there is a tax on your bill, you should calculate the tip based on the pretax amount, since the service is not really related to the tax. Additionally, the difference between a tip on the total (including tax) and the pretax amount is not significant. 

Q4: Is how much I tip based on the quality of service? 

A4: The answer is yes, and no. The proper etiquette is to tip regardless of terrible service, although doing so is still controversial. Why pay for terrible service, right? The key is to objectively judge the service, and the service alone. If the food is not good, the menu is sparse, the prices are outrageous, and/or the décor is appalling, all of this affects your dining experience, but is not the waiter’s fault. So identify what is in control of your waiter’s hands and what is not. And at the end of the day, have some compassion and practice giving the benefit of the doubt. If the service was not quite stellar, it may not be the waiter’s fault. Exceptions are if your waiter is rude or neglectful! 

Q5: How much to tip? 

A5: It’s great that you have an application in your hands to help you determine this! No matter how poor the quality of services was, leaving a tip of less than 10\%% will not be looked upon favorably nor will it paint you in a very good light, in case of future visits. Tips amounting to 18-20\%% of the total bill amount are interpreted to mean the service was satisfactory. Anything above 25\%% means that the services were excellent! Use this application, and share it with your friends to spread the practice of giving your waiters the royal tipping treatment!
